okay so the calcium reactor system in the UT3 process actually poses a significant materials concern primarily
because there's a 76% volutric difference in the structures between calcium oxide and calcium broomemide um
so during the typical UT3 process with the switching of flow you're going to have a expansion and contraction of
these solid reactants and products depending on the stage of the process which can cause fines to form and could
eventually lead to products centering after uh substantial cycling and so I
researched a couple designs to mitigate these problems and because we don't want our products to turn into powder and so
we looked at a couple designs that basically form a stable calcium oxide pellet that can be cycled multiple times
and last in the same order as the iron pellets which are much more stable structurally and so I'm going to
actually show you the design and then talk about it since it's more obvious so the global calcium pellet has a couple
of substructures nested in each other and so the first substructure you have the calcium titanium oxide which is just
used as a structural binder for the pellet which does not undergo substantial expansion or contraction
because the it doesn't actually react with any of the gaseous products it's just there for structural integrity and
then the calcium oxide pellets as you can see have uh they're not solid pellets like the calcium titanium oxide
and so there's actually voids presented in the calcium pellet which you can see in this even smallerru substructure um
and basically the calcium oxide as it's brominated into calcium broomemide expands due to the volutric difference
and the extra void between all the pellets initially allows these pellets to expand without exerting substantial
stresses on each adjacent particle the pore plugging so the the separation is
designed such that when all of the calcium oxide is eventually transformed into calcium broomemide is just at the
point before they're exerting substantial structural stresses on each other as to prevent um fines from
forming and other um bad things for the metals and so as a whole if you can just
cascade this back the c the calcium pellet globally will not expand too much
due d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d d to brination and even if it it's going to expand and contract some because just inherent in this design
however with the calcium titanium oxide coupled with a substantial space for calcium oxide expansion we can have a
calcium pellet that is structurally stable and exists on the same order as the iron pellets

in for us and so we going to gas and liquid um the thing about gas is that
it's at the very high pressure um 35 to 70 MPa and so in order to deal with the
stresses on that you need a very strong outer wall and it also has to be very thick and so that's best for small
amounts of hydrogen such as that's the one that's used in vehicles um if you
want to use hydrogen for that but for large amounts it's actually better to have liquid hydrogen um which is sort of
at a low pressure it is at -253° C and that needs to be kept like

out that because what you need is a good surface to volume ratio it gets better
as you get larger amounts of liquid hydrogen and so That means for the amount of hydrogen we want to store
